openpas.basics

Interface Literal

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    Assumption, Proposition

    public interface Literal
    A literal is the "atomic" building block of all propositional sentences. The Literal class encapsulates the logical literal for OpenPAS. A Literal instance is identified by its unique index number. It can represent the negated logical literal if the negation flag is set. Any instance of Literal with the same index number should be considered to be the same literal. We define three types of literals:
    1) proposition: A PAS proposition. An application-defined literal to correspond a proposition in the application domain.
    2) assumption: A PAS assumption. An extended proposition that has also a probability associated with it.
    3) special: A special type of proposition with pre-allocated index numbers to express falsity (False) and tautology (True).
    There's no limitation for the uniqueness of the name for object creation, but the PAS interface imposes name uniqueness in a given PAS instance. Special literals are used to construct True or False expressions and sentences. Depending on the expression type an empty expression may be True or False. A special literal isn't needed to represent this. But to represent the opposite a special literal is used. For example, an empty term is logically True. To create a term that's false we insert the special False literal into the term that makes it False. See StringOps for more on this.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Literal cloneLiteral()
      Clones this literal.
      Literal cloneNegated()
      Clones this literal but flips the negation flag such that a previously positive literal is negated, and a previously negated literal loses negation and becomes positive.
      java.lang.Integer getIndex()
      Returns the index for this Literal.
      java.lang.String getName()
      Returns the given name for this literal.
      boolean getNeg()
      Returns true if this is a negated Literal, false otherwise.
      Literal.LiteralType getType()
      Returns the type of this literal (see the interface documentation Literal for more).

      • getName

        java.lang.String getName()
        Returns the given name for this literal.
        Returns:

      • getNeg

        boolean getNeg()
        Returns true if this is a negated Literal, false otherwise.
        Returns:

      • getIndex

        java.lang.Integer getIndex()
        Returns the index for this Literal. For a given factory this should be unique across all literals such that two Literal instance with the same index number represent the same literal.
        Returns:

      • getType

        Literal.LiteralType getType()
        Returns the type of this literal (see the interface documentation Literal for more).
        Returns:

      • isAssumption

        boolean isAssumption()
        Returns true is this Literal is an assumption (ie. the type is Assumption).
        Returns:

      • isProposition

        boolean isProposition()
        Returns true is this Literal is a proposition (ie. the type is Proposition).
        Returns:

      • isSpecial

        boolean isSpecial()
        Returns true is this Literal is a special literal (ie. the type is Special). For example the literals True and False are special literals which are not propositions or assumptions.
        Returns:

      • cloneLiteral

        Literal cloneLiteral()
        Clones this literal.
        Returns:

      • cloneNegated

        Literal cloneNegated()
        Clones this literal but flips the negation flag such that a previously positive literal is negated, and a previously negated literal loses negation and becomes positive.
        Returns:
